title: Evolutionary Government: Origins and Consequences of Structural Change in Government
descriptions:
The "Evolutionary Government: Origins and Consequences of Structural Change in Government" grant proposal seeks to investigate the reasons behind government structural changes and their impact on policy. The study, named STATE-DNA, will delve into the interaction between a unit's structural features and its organizational and environmental context to understand the drivers of change. Hypotheses suggest that structural shifts in government are evolutionary responses managed by distinct units, influencing policy outcomes.

Utilizing a data set spanning from 1815 to 2025 and encompassing 150,000 units across six countries, the project will employ genetic measures and data assimilation techniques to assess structural changes. Key concepts such as structural change, units within ministries and agencies, and the decline of party government will be explored. Expected outcomes include a comprehensive data set on government structures, a systematic analysis of the effects of structural changes on policy, and predictive forecasting of future government changes.

The study aims to provide valuable insights into the dynamics of government evolution and its implications for policy-making. By shedding light on the origins and consequences of structural change, the research will contribute to a deeper understanding of governance processes and potentially inform strategies for more adaptive and effective government structures.
